Walking into her bedroom — which is dark because of a burnt-out overhead light bulb she cannot quite persuade the landlord to replace — Carmela Scarpulla lists the things she needs and cannot afford: “A dresser. A little table. A lamp.”

abstract: A mother is keeping her family focused on the future, with support from a Neediest Cases Fund charity.
snippet: A mother is keeping her family focused on the future, with support from a Neediest Cases Fund charity.
lead_paragraph: Maria Bruno’s strength and her desire to give back to her community were inspired by her mother, Laura Andrews. “She was a wonderful person,” Ms. Bruno said. “When you were down and you spoke to her, she had the power to lift you up.” Her home was a safe haven for other children in their Brooklyn neighborhood. When Ms. Andrews suddenly died two years ago at the age of 50, Ms. Bruno fell into a deep depression. At the time, she was attending college and working as a counselor for people living with H.I.V., but all of that became overwhelming. She lost her job and dropped out of school. Her three young children were struggling to cope as well.

abstract: The New York Times’s Fund traces its history to 1911. Since then, it has raised over $300 million.
snippet: The New York Times’s Fund traces its history to 1911. Since then, it has raised over $300 million.
lead_paragraph: For more than 100 years, The New York Times has asked readers for contributions to its Neediest Cases Fund, to give direct assistance to those who are less fortunate. In its first year, 1912, readers contributed $3,630.88. These days, The Fund regularly raises over $5.5 million annually, and over the years The Fund has raised more than $300 million.

byline.original: By C. Warren Moses and David R. Jones

abstract: She is neither a restaurant reviewer nor a rock star, but in Joanna Matcham's mind, she has a dream job. Ms. Matcham, 43, is a grocery bagger for a Brooklyn supermarket, a job she so enjoys that she recently asked her manager for longer  hours.         She is not doing it for the wages, though the money doesn't hurt. Ms. Matcham could just as well stay home with her mother and siblings, who had been her sole supporters before she landed the job at an Edwards supermarket last fall.
lead_paragraph: She is neither a restaurant reviewer nor a rock star, but in Joanna Matcham's mind, she has a dream job. Ms. Matcham, 43, is a grocery bagger for a Brooklyn supermarket, a job she so enjoys that she recently asked her manager for longer hours.

abstract: Mary Rodriguez, 70, a diabetic widow who raised 7 children and has 12 grandchildren, was awarded full custody of her great-grandson, Jayden, 3.
snippet: Mary Rodriguez, 70, a diabetic widow who raised 7 children and has 12 grandchildren, was awarded full custody of her great-grandson, Jayden, 3.
lead_paragraph: Mary Rodriguez, a diabetic widow, greeted a visitor recently without an umbrella in the rain outside the maze of brick buildings in the Brooklyn housing project where she lived. Her legs were swollen, and her flip-flops were drenched. She wobbled back in while mentioning she owned a walker.

abstract: New York Times Neediest Cases Fund has received nearly $870,000 more in contributions than it had by this point last year (M)
snippet: New York Times Neediest Cases Fund has received nearly $870,000 more in contributions than it had by this point last year (M)
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund has received nearly $870,000 more in contributions than it had by this point last year. If donations continue to flow in at the rate they did last year, the fund will have been given more money than in any other year in its 89-year history.

lead_paragraph: The first time Laurie Fleming visited New York City to see if it was the right fit, she knew she had to live here.
